Award.AwardTitle: Locomotion and Transport in a Liquid Crystal

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the proposed study is to investigate the fundamentals of swimming of microorganisms in liquid crystal environments. Swimming and swarming of microorganisms is a topic of considerable current interest, with a lot of research left to be done in the case of swimming in fluids that are more complex than water. Results of this work will deepen our understanding of the behavior of microorganisms in complex yet very relevant systems, such as mucus and biofilms. The PI will continue to participate in the Research Experiences for Teachers program, which invites K-12 teachers from local schools to the Brown campus to participate in laboratory research and course development projects during the summer, and in the Brown University Summer High School program , giving lectures and demonstrations on the physics of locomotion and liquid crystals. The PI will also contribute lectures and discussions to the Providence After School Alliance (PASA), a local organization that provides expanded learning opportunities to high school students.

The goal of the proposed research is to provide the theoretical framework for understanding the swimming of microorganisms in liquid crystal solutions. These liquid crystal solutions are model systems for the study of more complicated anisotropic biological systems, but are also interesting in their own right as a means for manipulating active colloidal particles. While the hydrodynamic interactions between microscopic swimmers in Newtonian fluids, such as water, have received a lot of attention, bacteria commonly colonize environments laden with polymers. Since these polymers are typically rod-like and aligned, these environments are often anisotropic. For example, extracellular DNA forms parallel bundles in biofilms, and bacteria have been observed to swim preferentially along the direction of alignment. Furthermore, several experimental groups have recently begun to study swimming bacteria in nontoxic synthetic liquid crystal solutions. The proposal is addressing this issue exactly, the development of a theory that would describe phenomena that are experimentally observed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluid mechanics has a strong effect on the behavior of swimming microorganisms such as bacteria or sperm cells, and fluid flow at the scale of the cell is very different from the fluid flow humans encounter in everyday life. Water at the scale of a biological cell is effectively very viscous. As a consequence, E. coli bacteria swim by rotating a slender helical propeller---a strategy that would fail completely for propelling a boat, but works at the small scale because the high viscous resistance to the propeller leads to propulsive force. The fluid mechanics of swimming bacteria or swimming sperm cells has been subject to intense study by scientists and engineers in recent years. However, swimming cells commonly encounter environments with more complex fluids, such as mucus in the airway, or cervical fluid. These fluids are laden with polymers, which are typically rod-like and aligned, making the fluid mechanical properties much more complex that that of water. The purpose of this project is to develop mathematical models that can be used to predict how a swimming microorganism moves in such a fluid. Since mucus is a very complex material, we use a simpler model fluid which is a nematic liquid crystal. A nematic liquid crystal is a fluid comprised of rod-shaped molecules, in which the molecules all point spontaneously in the same direction, even in the absence of any external aligning effect. Liquid crystals are familiar from the displays in our phones and computers, but they are also a subject of research in their own right. Recently, scientists have studied swimming bacterial in nontoxic liquid crystals, and shown that bacteria tend to swim parallel to the rod-shaped molecules. The intellectual merit of this project is that the distinctive properties of liquid crystals have a profound influence on swimming behavior, leading to novel effects on swimming trajectory, the alignment of swimmers, and interactions between a swimmer a confining wall. For example, we calculated the swimming speed as a function of the angle between the swimmer and the direction of the rods in an nematic liquid crystal, and showed that the rods exert an elastic torque that tends to align the swimmer with the rod direction. We also showed that for certain parameters of the liquid crystal (i.e. high rotational viscosity, which is the viscous resistance to rotating the rods about their centers of mass), a swimmer in a liquid crystal will swim in the opposite direction as a swimmer with the same stroke in water. Finally, we showed that for a swimmer in a liquid crystal near a wall, the liquid crystalline effects tend to die away the closer the swimmer is to the wall. The chief broader impacts of this work is that liquid crystalline solutions may be used as a simple way to control the direction of swimming of bacteria or sperm cells, and our mathematical calculations give precise quantitative predictions about when liquid crystalline effects are important. 

 A separate line of inquiry in our field is the study of active fluids. An active fluid is one in which the motion of the fluid is powered by many individual energy-consuming agents in the fluid, rather than an external energy source like a fan or a pump. The cytoplasm inside a crawling amoeba is an example of an active fluid, because the crawling motion is generated by molecular motors that consume ATP and slide filaments past each other to deform pseudopods. Since the filaments tend to align, active fluids are typically also liquid crystalline. Scientists are beginning to study simple experimental models of active fluids, which led us to study the problem of a swimmer in an active fluid (e.g. a small bacterium in a very large cell).  Our calculations showed that it is possible for a swimmer to extract energy from the active fluid and swim faster than a swimmer with the same stroke in a fluid that is not active.  The broader impact of this work is the potential to construct microswimmers that are in part powered by the fluid in which they swim.
